teachingScript.overview: A short paragraph that the teacher can read to introduce the lesson (2-4 sentences).

stepByStep.teacherLines: What the teacher says (dialogue-style) — simple, classroom friendly language.
stepByStep.studentActivity: What students should do/respond during this step.

stepByStep.teacherLines: Teacher explanation for a key concept.
stepByStep.studentActivity: Guided questions or quick checks for understanding.

teachingScript.transitions: Short phrases to move between segments (e.g. 'Now that we have seen X, let's try Y').

subtopics.title: Subtopic title
subtopics.explanation: Teacher friendly expanded explanation of the subtopic with examples.

formulasAndDerivations.derivationOrUse: Brief derivation or how to use the formula in class problems

activities.warmUpHook: One-sentence activity to grab attention (e.g. quick thought experiment).

interactive.name: Activity name
interactive.type: class discussion / demo / video / interactive experiment
interactive.expectedOutcome: What students will observe or learn from the activity

practiceProblems.answer: expected short answer or calculation outline

groupWork.task: One-sentence group task (e.g. make a poster, build a model)
groupWork.successCriteria: What a good group output looks like

wrapUp.summary: 3-5 concise bullet sentences that restate the lesson's key takeaways.
wrapUp.closureActivity: One-line activity to finish class (e.g. quick exit ticket prompt).

quickAssessment.formatHints: Specify whether Qs are MCQ / short answer / calculation and marks for each (e.g. 1 mark each).

assessment.exitTicket: One-sentence prompt for students to complete before leaving (e.g. 'Write one new thing you learned and one question you still have').
assessment.homework: Short homework assignment aligned with objectives (what to research or practice).
assessment.rubricOrMarkingHints: Short descriptors for quick marking (e.g. full / partial / no credit criteria).

additionalReadingOrMedia: Short article or video title with brief note on use (no external links)

differentiation.strugglingLearners: Concrete scaffolds, sentence starters, simplified diagrams, pairing with peers.
differentiation.advancedStudents: Extension tasks, deeper problem solving or mini-research prompts.
differentiation.multipleLearningStyles: How to present (visual / kinesthetic / auditory) — e.g. diagrams, hands-on demo, spoken summary.

formattingGuidelinesForOutput.languageTone: Simple, teacher-friendly, conversational (avoid overly technical jargon).
formattingGuidelinesForOutput.diagramPlaceholders: Include [Diagram Placeholder: short descriptor] exactly where teacher should draw or project diagrams.
formattingGuidelinesForOutput.tables: Use small comparison tables (max 4-5 rows) for quick board writing.

lengthHints.assessmentQ: Short and precise — one line per Q

formattingGuidelinesForOutput.jsonValidationNotes: All text fields must be strings; lists must be arrays. Replace placeholder strings with actual content when generating session output.
